children.name: get upset
examples: I get upset when I see people being cruel to animals.
▪ At the slightest mention of her ex-husband’s name she gets upset.

children.name: get upset about
examples: ▪ It was an awful thing for him to say, but there’s no point in getting upset about it.

children.name: take st to heart
children.definition: take something to heart  to be more upset by what someone says than they intended you to be:
examples: ▪ Don’t take anything he said to heart - he was drunk.
▪ Brian is a very sensitive kind of person and he takes criticism very much to heart.

children.name: get het up
children.definition: especially British, informal to become very upset about something in a way that other people think is unnecessary:
examples: ▪ There’s no need to get so het up - it’s only a driving test!

children.name: get worked up
children.definition: to become very upset or angry, so that you think things are worse than they really are:
examples: ▪ I’ll tell you what he said, but promise you won’t get worked up.

children.name: get worked up about/over
examples: ▪ It’s not worth getting worked up about. Anyone can make a mistake.

children.name: get (yourself) all worked up
examples: ▪ If there’s nothing you can do, why get yourself all worked up, honey?

children.name: hurt
children.definition: upset and shocked because someone has been unkind to you, especially someone that you trusted and thought was a friend:
examples: ▪ Bill felt very hurt when he realized she had lied to him.
hurt[uncountable noun]
▪ Sylvie could still remember the hurt of being treated like an outsider.

children.name: hurt (that)
examples: ▪ Gretta was really hurt that none of her friends came to visit her in the hospital.

children.name: deeply hurtextremely hurt
examples: ▪ Jackson was said to be ‘deeply hurt’ by the newspaper reports about him.

children.name: distraught
children.definition: extremely upset, usually because you are very worried about something, so that you cry a lot or seem confused:
examples: ▪ He could see that I was distraught, but he still kept asking me questions.
▪ The distraught parents of the missing baby have made a public appeal for her return.

children.name: distraught at/over/about
examples: ▪ We were all distraught about the accident, but Mama was the most upset.
▪ Benson was so distraught over the breakup of his marriage that he committed suicide.

children.name: distraught that
examples: ▪ Casey was totally distraught that they were throwing him out of school.

children.name: be in a state
children.definition: British informal to be so upset that you cannot stop crying or control your emotions:
examples: ▪ Stephan called me in a state, saying he was thinking of killing himself.
▪ The children were in such a state that the police couldn’t question them.

children.name: be in an awful/terrible/shocking etc state
examples: ▪ He’s been in a terrible state since Julie left him.

children.name: distressed
children.definition: extremely upset and shocked about something very unpleasant that has happened, so that you cry or become confused:
examples: ▪ Herman becomes distressed when anyone asks him about the accident.
▪ The airport was full of distressed relatives waiting for news of the crash.
distress[uncountable noun]
▪ Mr and Mrs Roberts spoke with obvious distress about their missing daughter.

children.name: distressed by/about/at
examples: ▪ Everyone in the office was distressed by Maggie’s unexpected death.
▪ Nelson’s supporters were distressed about his use of racial slurs.

children.name: distressed that
examples: ▪ I was crying all the time, and my mother was distressed that she could do nothing to comfort me.

children.name: distressed to hear/learn/see/find etc
examples: ▪ We were all distressed to hear that Stuart had been attacked the night before.

children.name: deeply distressedextremely distressed
examples: ▪ She was deeply distressed to see the animal in so much pain.

children.name: upset
children.definition: unhappy because something very unpleasant or disappointing has happened, so that you feel shocked or you want to cry:
examples: ▪ Miss Hurley is too upset to speak to anyone at the moment.
▪ The children were very upset when we told them that we wouldn’t be going to Disneyland.

children.name: upset about
examples: ▪ She’s still upset about her uncle’s death.

children.name: upset (that)
examples: ▪ The organizers were upset that so few people visited the exhibition.

children.name: upsetting
examples: ▪ She can’t talk about her son’s death - she finds it too upsetting.
▪ Many adults manage to forget their more upsetting childhood experiences.

children.name: it is upsetting to do something
examples: ▪ It was upsetting to have to say goodbye so soon.

children.name: painful
children.definition: a painful experience or memory makes you feel extremely upset and sad:
examples: ▪ It’s five years since we separated, but I still find the memories quite painful.
▪ For those involved, the scandal has been a very painful experience.

children.name: painful to
examples: ▪ Colin’s death is painful to me and everyone who knew him.

children.name: it is painful to see/hear etc
examples: ▪ It was so painful to see how frail she had become in just a few months.

children.name: traumatic
children.definition: an experience or event that is traumatic makes you feel so upset that it affects the way you think or behave for a very long time:
examples: ▪ Len’s slow and painful death was traumatic for the entire family.
▪ Learning to swim was the most traumatic experience of my childhood.

children.name: distressing
children.definition: making you feel extremely upset or worried:

children.name: ▪ U.N. officials have called the recent arrest of political opponents ‘distressing.’
examples: ▪ Being in a strange city with no money was an extremely distressing situation.

children.name: harrowing
children.definition: an experience or event that is harrowing makes you feel extremely upset because it is very frightening or shocking:
examples: ▪ The film contained harrowing scenes of starving children.
▪ After a harrowing bus ride through the mountains, we arrived at the port of Heraklion.

children.name: offend
children.definition: to make someone angry or upset by doing something that they think is socially or morally unacceptable or by being rude to them: Xúc phạm
examples: ▪ The programme contains scenes that may offend older viewers.
Chương trình này chứa những cảnh khiến khán giả lớn tuổi bị xúc phạm.
▪ She stopped mid-sentence, anxious not to offend him.
Cô ấy dừng lại nửa câu để không xúc phạm anh ta.
▪ He didn’t speak during the meeting for fear of saying something that might offend.
Anh ta không nói tiếng nào trong suốt cuộc họp để tránh những lời có thể gây xúc phạm người khác.
offend (somebody’s) sensibilities: Làm ai đó bị tổn thương.
▪ He is a sensitive man, and it is not difficult to offend his sensibilities.
Anh ta là một người nhạy cảm vì thế không khó để làm anh ta bị tổn thương.

children.name: insult
children.definition: to make someone very angry and upset, for example by doing something that shows you have little respect for them or do not think that they are very good at something: Lăng mạ
examples: ▪ In some cultures, you insult your host if you do not accept their offer of food.
Ở một số nền văn hóa, bạn sẽ lăng mạ chủ nhà nếu bạn không hài lòng với sự phuc vụ thức ăn của họ.
insult somebody by doing something: sĩ nhục ai đó
▪ I won’t insult you by explaining the rules of the game.
Tôi sẽ không sĩ nhục bạn với việc giải thích luật lệ trò chơi.
insult somebody’s intelligence : Lăng mạ sự thông minh của người khác
treat someone as if they are stupid
▪ questions that insult the intelligence of the interviewee
Những câu hỏi này lang mạ trí thông minh của ứng cử viên phỏng vấn.
insult/ˈɪnsʌlt/ [countable noun]: sự xúc phạm
▪ She took it as a personal insult that you did not ask her opinion about your book.
Cô áy xem việc bạn mượn sách mà không hỏi ý kiến cô ấy như là sự xúc phạm cá nhân.

children.name: get/put sb’s back up
children.definition: get/put somebody’s back up  British informal to make someone annoyed, especially without intending to: lám cho ai đó bực mình
examples: ▪ It really gets my back up when salesmen call round to the house.
Điếu đó thật sự làm tôi bực mình khi người bán hàng gọi to tên tôi.
▪ He treats everyone like children, and that’s why he puts people’s backs up.
Anh ấy đối xử với mọi người như trẻ con, và đó là lý do tại sao anh ấy làm cho họ bực mình.

children.name: cause offence
children.definition: to offend someone - use this about words or actions that were not intended to offend anyone: Vô tình xúc phạm.
examples: ▪ He later appeared on television to apologize for causing offence.
Anh ấy xuất hiện trên ti vi để xin lỗi về việc đã vô tình xúc phục.

children.name: cause offence to: Làm phật lòng ai đó
examples: ▪ I hope I didn’t cause offence to anyone when I left early.
Tôi hy vọng tôi không làm phật lòng ai khi tôi ra về sớm.
cause great offence: Gây ra sự xúc phạm lớn.
▪ A remark that is considered humorous in one culture can cause great offence in another.
Điều đang chú ý là cái tính hài hước ở một số nền văn hóa được xem là sự xúc phạm to lớn đói vói người khác.

children.name: offended
children.definition: rất khó chịu
examples: ▪ She’ll be offended if you don’t say thank you for her help.
Cô ấy sẽ rất khó chịu nếu bạn không nói cảm ơn khi cô ấy giúp đỡ bạn.
offended by: khó chịu vì..
▪ He’s always offended by jokes aimed at Irish people.
Anh ấy luôn khó chịu bởi những trò đùa nhằm vào người Irish
offended that: khó chịu rằng
▪ He felt offended that she didn’t want to go out with him.
Anh ta cảm thấy khó chịu rằng cô ấy không muốn đi chơi với anh ta
deeply offended: cực kì khó chịu
▪ Some people may find rude jokes funny, but others may be deeply offended.
Một số người có lẽ sẽ thấy những trò đùa thật buồn cười, nhưng những người khác thì cực kì khó chịu

children.name: insulted
children.definition: very angry and upset, for example because someone has done something that shows they have little respect for you or your abilities: bị lăng mạ, xúc phạm
examples: ▪ Molly would be insulted if we didn’t go and see her while we were in town.
Molly sẽ cảm thấy bị lăng mạ nếu chúng tôi không đến gặp cô ấy khi chúng tôi ở trong thị trấn này.
insulted by: bị xúc phạm bởi
▪ Please don’t be insulted by anything I say.
Làm ơn đừng bị xúc phạm bởi bất kì những lời tôi nói
insulted that; bị xúc phạm vì
▪ He felt insulted that they had not told him about the party.
Anh ta cảm thấy bị xúc phạm khi họ không nói với anh ta về buổi tiệc.
deeply insulted: cực kì bị xúc phạm
▪ We must eat as much as possible, or she will be deeply insulted.
Chúng tôi phải ăn thật nhiều nếu không cô ấy sẽ cảm thấy cực kì bị xúc phạm

children.name: slighted
children.definition: offended, especially because someone has not included you in their plans: bị coi thường
examples: ▪ The guest list was very short, so no-one felt slighted because they hadn’t been invited.
Danh sách khách mời rất ít, vì vậy không ai cảm thấy bị coi thường khi họ không được mời.

children.name: put out
children.definition: offended and surprised, especially because you feel that you have not been treated fairly: khó chịu
examples: ▪ When she said I was interfering, I was a bit put out.
Khi cô ấy nói tôi đang can thiệp vào, tôi rất khó chịu
put out about:khó chịu về
▪ She was rather put out about being described as plain.
put out by: khó chịu bởi
▪ The minister was not put out by the note of impatience in Cohen’s voice.
Bộ trưởng không khó chịu về những ghi chú nhưng bởi sụ thiếu kiên nhẫn trong giọng của Cohen

children.name: take offence
children.definition: to feel offended by something someone says or does, especially something that does not seem serious to other people: giận
examples: ▪ Don’t mention her hairstyle. She’ll probably take offence.
Đừng đề cập đến tóc của cô ấy nữa, cô ấy sẽ giận đó.
▪ Please don’t take offence, but I would prefer you not to swear in front of the children.
Làm ơn đừng giận nhưng tôi muốn bạn đừng thề thốt trước mặt bọn trẻ hơn.
take offence at: tức giận về..
▪ He didn’t seem to take offence at my lack of enthusiasm for his idea.
Anh ta dường như không tức giận vì sự thiếu nhiệt tình của tôi đối với ý kiến của anh ấy.

children.name: be quick to take offence: dễ giận
examples: ▪ He described her as a woman who is temperamental and quick to take offence.
Anh ta mô ta cô ấy là một người phụ nữ nóng tính và dễ giận hờn.

children.name: take st personally
children.definition: take something personally  to feel offended by something, especially a criticism, even though it was not aimed at one particular person: cảm thấy bị xúc phạm
examples: ▪ Anna took it personally when the boss said some people were not working hard enough.

children.name: Anna bị xúc phạm khi giám đốc nói rằng nhiều người đã làm việc không đủ cham chỉ
examples: ▪ This is a general criticism, so I hope none of you will take it personally.

children.name: Đây là lời phê bình chung, vì thế tôi hy vọng không ai trong số các bạn
examples: ▪ I didn’t take his rebuff too personally, since I was used to his habit of being rude to his juniors.
Tôi không cảm thấy bị xúc phạm nhiều, bởi vì tôi đã quen với thói thô lỗ của anh ấy với những người cấp dưới.

children.name: take st the wrong way
children.definition: take something the wrong way  to be offended by something someone says or does when it was not intended to offend you and you have understood it in the wrong way: hiểu lầm
examples: ▪ Daniel sat in silence, afraid whatever he said would be taken the wrong way.

children.name: Daniel ngồi im lặng e là những gì anh ấy nói đã bị hiểu lầm
examples: ▪ Don’t take this the wrong way, but your driving has really improved.

children.name: Nói cậu đừng hiểu nhầm nhé! nhưng thật sự tài lái xe của cậu đã được cải thiện
take exception to
children.definition: to feel offended by something someone says, and to make it clear that you feel this way:phản đối cái gì
examples: ▪ I took exception to what he said about my family.
Tôi phản đối những gì anh ta nói về gia đình tôi
▪ Paul took exception to her advice, which he said undermined his self-esteem.
Paul phản đối lời khuyên của cô ấy, anh ta nói điều này sẽ làm mất lòng tự trọng của anh ấy
take great exception to something: rất phản đối, rất bất bình
▪ I take great exception to the suggestion that I neglected my responsibilities.
Tôi rất bất bình trước lời ý kiến tôi lơ là trách nhiệm của mình

children.name: sensitive
examples: ▪ My brother pretends he’s tough, but he’s actually pretty sensitive.

children.name: sensitive about
examples: ▪ I didn’t realize that Lee was so sensitive about her family.

children.name: sensitive to criticism
examples: ▪ If you are a public figure you can’t afford to be too sensitive to criticism.

children.name: oversensitive/overly sensitive
children.definition: use this about someone who you think gets upset too easily:
examples: ▪ When I complain about the mean things he says, he just tells me I’m being oversensitive.
▪ Overly sensitive children have trouble making friends with other children.

children.name: be/get easily offended
children.definition: : Dễ bị xúc phạm.
examples: ▪ Be careful what you say to Jenny; she’s oversensitive and easily offended.
Hãy cẩn thận với những gì mà bạn nói vói Jenny, cô ấy rất nhạy cảm và dễ bị xúc phạm.

children.name: be/get easily offended by: dễ khó chịu về điều gì
examples: ▪ Barry gets easily offended by comments about his parents’ divorce.
Bary dễ cảm thấy khó chịu với những lời nhận xét về việc ly hôn của ba mẹ cô ấy.

children.name: touchy
children.definition: too easily offended, especially so that people are afraid to talk to you, or offer advice: nhạy cảm
examples: ▪ Some authors get very touchy if you make even the slightest alteration to their work.

children.name: Nhiều tác giả rất nhạy cảm nếu bạn thay thế dù là rất nhỏ tác phẩm của họ
examples: ▪ Why are you so touchy today?
Tại sao hôm nay bạn nhạy cảm thế?

children.name: touchy about: nhạy cảm về việc
examples: ▪ He’s a great manager, but he is very touchy about his lack of qualifications.
Anh ấy là một nhà quản lí tuyệt vời, nhưng anh ta rất nhạy cảm về sự thiếu bằng cấp của mình.

children.name: sensitive
children.definition: very easily offended by a particular thing: nhạy cảm
examples: ▪ Paul is too sensitive for this job. He can’t take even the smallest criticism.
Paul quá nhạy cảm với công viêc. Anh ấy thậm chí không thể chịu đựng nổi những lời phê bình nhỏ nhặt.

children.name: sensitive about: Nhạy cảm với viêc gì
examples: ▪ He’s sensitive about his bad teeth, so try not to look at them.
Anh ấy nhạy cảm với hãm răng xấu xí của mình, vì vậy đừng nhìn chúng.
▪ My children are very sensitive about being treated in a patronising way.
Các con của tôi rât nhạy cảm khi bị đới xử một cách kẻ cả.

children.name: prude
children.definition: someone who is easily offended by anything that is rude or connected with sex, especially in a way that other people think is unnecessary: người cả thẹn
examples: ▪ Sarah’s no prude, but she thought some of the sex scenes were quite shocking.
Sarah không phải là người cả thẹn, nhưng cô ấy lại nghĩ những cảnh tình dục khà kinh tởm.

children.name: over-sensitive
children.definition: someone who is over-sensitive gets offended and upset very easily, because they always think other people are criticizing them, making fun of them etc: dễ nhạy cảm
examples: ▪ It’s not unusual for artists to be over-sensitive about their work.

children.name: Không có gì bất thường nếu những người họa sĩ dễ nhạy cảm với những công việc của họ
examples: ▪ Of course he wasn’t saying you were overweight - you’re just being over-sensitive.

children.name: Tất nhiên là anh ấy không nói bạn tăng rồi, bạn chỉ dễ nhạy cảm thôi
hurt
children.definition: to make someone feel upset by being unkind to them or not thinking enough about their feelings, especially someone who trusts you and thinks you are their friend:

children.name: ▪ I would never do anything to hurt her
examples: ▪ The fact that his parents take little interest in his life hurts him more than he admits.

children.name: it hurts somebody to see/hear/learn etc
examples: ▪ It hurts me to think that you still don’t trust me.

children.name: hurt sb’s feelings
children.definition: hurt somebody’s feelings  to make someone feel upset or offended by something that you say or do, often unintentionally:

children.name: ▪ I’m sorry if I hurt your feelings, but I was just being honest
examples: .▪ Don’t tell your sister what William said - you’ll only hurt her feelings.
▪ I didn’t tell him I don’t like his haircut - I don’t want to hurt his feelings.

children.name: distress
children.definition: to make someone feel extremely upset or worried:
examples: ▪ The number of young men who called asking for Marie distressed her mother.

children.name: it distresses somebody to see/hear etc
examples: ▪ It distressed him to see Susie cry.

children.name: upset
examples: ▪ I’m sorry if I upset you - I didn’t mean to.

children.name: ▪ ‘Why’s he crying?’ ‘I don’t know - something must have upset him.’
examples: ▪ Try not to upset your father. He’s had a hard day.

children.name: it upsets somebody to see/hear/think etc
examples: ▪ It still upsets me to think about my parents’ divorce.

children.name: what upsets somebody is
examples: ▪ What upsets me most is the way she lied to me.
